<Summary source="https://tradingeconomics.com/united-states/case-shiller-home-price-index">
# Summary of Article on S&P Case-Shiller 20-City Composite Home Price Index

**Important Note:** This article discusses the **20-City Composite Index**, not the **US National Home Price Index** that is the subject of the forecasting question. These are related but distinct indices.

## Key Facts and Statistics:

1. **Recent Values (20-City Composite Index):**
   - November 2025: 337.27 points
   - October 2025: 337.37 points
   - This represents a decrease of 0.10 points month-over-month

2. **Historical Context:**
   - Historical average (2000-2025): 195.54 points
   - All-time high: 343.03 points (May 2025)
   - Record low: 100.00 points (January 2000)

3. **Forecasts from Trading Economics:**
   - End of current quarter expectation: 344.03 points
   - 2027 projection: 349.86 points
   - 2028 projection: 357.91 points
   - Source: Trading Economics global macro models and analysts expectations

## Index Coverage:
The 20-City Composite measures home prices across: Atlanta, Boston, Charlotte, Chicago, Cleveland, Dallas, Denver, Detroit, Las Vegas, Los Angeles, Miami, Minneapolis, New York, Phoenix, Portland, San Diego, San Francisco, Seattle, Tampa, and Washington D.C.

## Data Characteristics:
- Frequency: Monthly
- Base: 2000 M1 = 100
- Format: Not seasonally adjusted (NSA)
</Summary>

# Summary of Article: S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller Home Price Indices

**Source:** Federal Reserve Economic Data (FRED), St. Louis Fed

## Key Facts and Statistics:

### National Index (Seasonally Adjusted):
- **November 2025**: 330.447 (Index Jan 2000=100)
- **October 2025** (Preceding Period): 329.139
- **November 2024** (Year Ago): 325.951

### Composite Indices for November 2025:
- **10-City Composite**: 361.06727 (preceding: 359.31412, year ago: 353.91444)
- **20-City Composite**: 340.73354 (preceding: 339.12184, year ago: 335.95592)

The article provides seasonally adjusted home price indices for 20 metropolitan areas, including:

(Additional cities listed with their respective index values)

## Notes:
This appears to be a data table from FRED showing the most recent Case-Shiller Home Price Index values. The data is presented as seasonally adjusted monthly figures with the base period of January 2000 = 100. The article is purely factual/statistical in nature with no analysis or opinions provided.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.jpmorgan.com/insights/global-research/real-estate/us-housing-market-outlook">
# Summary of J.P. Morgan US Housing Market Outlook (January 27, 2026)

## Key Facts and Statistics:

**House Price Forecasts:**
- J.P. Morgan Global Research expects U.S. house prices to stall at **0% growth in 2026**
- House prices have nearly doubled in the last decade
- Regional variations exist: prices falling most along West Coast and Sun Belt due to pandemic-era construction boom glut

**Housing Supply:**
- J.P. Morgan estimates the U.S. housing shortage at approximately **1.2 million homes** (significantly below other market estimates)
- Supply of single-family homes has increased in recent months
- Over the past 30 years, new household formations and housing completions net out to nearly zero

**Recent Sales Data:**
- December 2025 existing home sales grew by **5.1%** (seasonally adjusted) to reach a nearly three-year high
- September and October 2025 new home sales exceeded expectations
- Mortgage rates fell nearly **75 basis points** from late-May to mid-September 2025

**Affordability:**
- National Association of Realtors' affordability index was **35% below pre-COVID levels** in November
- House price-to-income ratio remains near historic highs for the last three years
- Fixed-rate mortgage rates projected to stay elevated at **6+%**

**Policy Impacts:**
- Trump administration's $200 billion MBS purchase program accounts for only **~1.4% of the ~$14.5 trillion mortgage market**
- Expected to reduce 30-year mortgage yields by only **10-15 basis points** at most
- Institutional investors make up only **1-3% of the market**

## Named Source Opinions:

**John Sim, Head of Securitized Products Research, J.P. Morgan:**
- Expects adjustable-rate mortgage rates could tick downward if Fed eases
- Notes homebuilders continuing to offer rate buydowns to clear inventory
- States: "Supply is a key factor in areas where we see home prices decline"
- Warns: "Overbuilding is a sure path to home price declines"

**Joseph Lupton, Global Economist, J.P. Morgan:**
- Explains higher policy rates kept prices high by making homeowners reluctant to move and sacrifice lower mortgage rates
- Notes labor market hiring rate has slowed to near recession lows, restricting housing market activity

**Michael Feroli, Chief U.S. Economist, J.P. Morgan:**
- Cautions that residual seasonality in existing sales could be overstating improvement
- Expects home sales to improve gradually
- Will watch pending home sales data to gauge sustained momentum

**Michael Rehaut, Head of U.S. Homebuilding and Building Products Research, J.P. Morgan:**
- Notes most homebuilders already offer mortgage rate buydowns of **100-200 basis points** below prevailing rates
- Believes modest lowering of market mortgage rate won't have material impact on demand
- Warns institutional investor ban could potentially tighten overall supply if it prevents build-to-rent communities

**Anthony Paolone, Co-head of U.S. Real Estate Stock Research, J.P. Morgan:**
- Estimates institutional investor ban impact on landlords as small: "perhaps less than a 1% annual headwind to NOI for a couple of years"
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.marketplace.org/story/2025/12/18/the-2026-housing-market-expectations-and-predictions">
# Summary of "Housing reset" forecast for 2026

## Key Facts and Statistics:

**2025 Market Performance:**
- Sales of both existing and new homes were lackluster due to high borrowing costs, high prices, and economic uncertainty

**2026 Forecasts:**

*Mortgage Rates:*
- Expected to stay around 6.3% for a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage (Redfin forecast)

*Home Sales:*
- Existing home sales predicted to increase modestly by 3% (Redfin)

*Home Prices:*
- National home price increase of 2.2% (Realtor.com forecast by Jake Krimmel)
- 1% price increase (Redfin forecast by Daryl Fairweather)

*Income Growth:*
- Household incomes expected to rise 4% (Realtor.com)
- Incomes predicted to rise faster than home prices for the first prolonged period since the Great Recession

*New Home Construction:*
- Single-family construction expected to fall about 3% (John Burns Research and Consulting)
- Homebuilders report highest unsold, finished inventory since January 2010

## Named Expert Opinions:

**Daryl Fairweather, Chief Economist at Redfin:**
- Predicts a yearslong "housing reset" beginning in 2026 with gradually improving affordability
- Attributes improvement to mortgage rates coming down and stabilizing

**Jake Krimmel, Senior Economist at Realtor.com:**
- Expects the most balanced housing market in about a decade, with neither buyers nor sellers having an upper hand in negotiations
- Describes the trend as "moving in the right direction for the market"

**Rick Palacios Jr., Director of Research at John Burns Research and Consulting:**
- Expects a "pretty glacial housing market" in 2026
- Cites affordability issues and consumer hesitancy due to economic conditions

## Important Caveats Noted:
- Regional differences could affect outcomes
- Job market, tariffs, inflation, and Federal Reserve leadership change are all unknowns that could impact predictions
- Rental market outlook is mixed with forecasts ranging from slight decline to modest growth
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://fortune.com/2026/02/09/housing-market-outlook-forecast-home-prices-0-percent-growth-2026-trump-mortgage-rates/">
## Summary of JPMorgan's Nationwide Home Price Forecast Article

### Key Facts and Statistics:

1. **JPMorgan's 2026 Forecast**: Home price growth will stall at 0% in 2026, after nearly doubling over the past decade.

2. **Recent Price Growth Data**: According to the Federal Housing Finance Agency's most recent data, home prices in November were up 1.9% year-over-year, down sharply from 4.8% annual growth in October.

3. **Regional Declines**: 
   - Texas home prices are down 2.4% year-over-year (according to Zillow)
   - Florida home prices are down 5.1% year-over-year (according to Zillow)
   - Prices are falling quickest on the West Coast and in the Sunbelt

4. **Housing Supply Shortfall**: JPMorgan estimates the overall U.S. housing market has a shortfall of about 1.2 million homes (though this is noted as "well below the consensus view")

5. **Institutional Investor Market Share**: Institutional investors account for only 1% to 3% of the market

6. **Trump Administration Mortgage Intervention**: The $200 billion purchase of mortgage-backed securities by Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae represents just 1.4% of the $14.5 trillion mortgage market

### Named Source Opinions:

**John Sim, Head of Securitized Products Research at JPMorgan:**
- Expects demand to shift higher while supply increases subside due to dips in adjustable-rate mortgages, homebuilder rate buydowns, and rising wealth effect
- Notes that "overbuilding is a sure path to home price declines, and builders have been navigating an increasing supply of new homes"

**Michael Rehaut, Head of U.S. Homebuilding and Building Products Research at JPMorgan:**
- Believes Trump's proposed ban on institutional investors purchasing single-family homes "is unlikely to be a game changer"
- Notes the ban could "potentially have the opposite effect and theoretically tighten overall supply" if it prevents large operators from building rental homes
- States the $200 billion mortgage-backed securities purchase could cut rates by 10 to 15 basis points at most
- Notes most homebuilders already offer mortgage rate buydowns of 100 to 200 basis points, so "a modest lowering of the market mortgage rate will have a material impact on demand"

**President Donald Trump (Jan. 29 cabinet meeting):**
- "I don't want to drive housing prices down. I want to drive housing prices up for people that own their homes, and they can be assured that's what's going to happen"

### Market Dynamics:

- 30-year fixed mortgage rates expected to stay above 6%
- Muted demand in recent months forced some sellers to pull listings or slash asking prices
- Housing completions have essentially matched household formation over the past 30 years
- Pandemic-era construction boom created supply overhang, particularly in Texas and Florida
</Summary>

<Asknews_articles>
Query: What will be the seasonally adjusted S&P/Case-Shiller US National Home Price Index in the following months? (Jan-26)
Here are the relevant news articles:

**National Housing Market Shows First Signs of Stabilization in January 2026**
In January 2026, China's real estate market showed early signs of stabilization, particularly in the secondary housing market. National key 13 cities recorded a 16% month-on-month increase and a 33% year-on-year rise in second-hand home transaction volume, reaching 8.1 million square meters—18% higher than the 2025 monthly average. The transaction volume of 22 cities rose to 2.79 million square meters, the highest since June 2025, with year-on-year growth turning positive at 17.7%. Nationwide, 26 key cities saw a 27.0% year-on-year increase in real-time transaction contracts, with a 18.5% month-on-month rise. Price trends also stabilized: the national second-hand home listing price decline narrowed to 0.7% month-on-month (from 1.3% in previous months), with first-tier, second-tier, and third-tier cities all showing reduced monthly drops. The average price in 100 cities was 12,900 yuan per square meter, down 0.85% month-on-month, but with a narrowing decline. Core cities like Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen reported strong performance: Beijing surpassed 15,000 transactions, Shanghai hit a five-year high with 22,800 transactions, Guangzhou reached 8,881 transactions, and Shenzhen saw a 45.5% year-on-year increase. Market sentiment improved, with housing inventory falling and bargaining power shifting to sellers. In Beijing, one agent noted prices in a school district rose 100,000–150,000 yuan after policy changes. The 'iceberg index'—a proxy for real-time transaction activity—rose 14% month-on-month, with Xiamen leading at 34%. Experts like Cao Jingjing (CPII) and Wu Jing (Tsinghua) suggest a 'small spring' (xiao yangchun) in Q1 2026 is likely, driven by stabilized demand in core cities, policy effects, and seasonal factors. However, new home sales declined: 50 key cities saw a 32% month-on-month drop in transaction volume. The overall market remains in a downward trend, but signs point to a bottoming-out phase. Long-term indicators—such as stabilized demand in 40 cities (388 million sqm in 2025 vs. 393 million sqm in 2024), rising rental yields (2.39% in Dec 2025), and falling price-to-income ratios—support a market near valuation bottom. Shanghai launched a new pilot program to acquire second-hand homes for affordable rental housing in three districts (Jing’an, Pudong, Xuhui), with a projected need of 31.5 billion yuan. The 'old-to-new' exchange policy aims to reduce transaction costs (saving ~10% in commissions), support homeowners, and boost new home sales, but challenges remain: valuation discrepancies, limited buyer choice, and weak income expectations. Experts emphasize the need for institutional support, streamlined processes, and stronger coordination. Despite early signs of recovery, a nationwide rebound will require a longer cycle. Monitoring indicators include: (1) 100-city second-hand home prices stable (±0.2% monthly for three months), (2) 35 key cities’ monthly transaction volume at ~300,000 units, and (3) average listing duration under 90 days.
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 10, 2026 10:56 AM
Source:[凤凰网（凤凰新媒体）](https://finance.ifeng.com/c/8qdSUf5gurd)

**Which Real Estate Indicators Are Improving?**
Recent real estate data in China shows mixed trends in early 2026. For second-hand homes, sales declines have narrowed after adjusting for lunar calendar alignment, with national and first-tier city sales down -16% and -26.8% year-on-year, respectively, slightly improving from December 2025's -27.1% and -31.4%. Price declines have also eased, with the national average dropping 0.85% month-on-month in January 2026—narrowing from December’s 0.97%—and key cities like Beijing and Shanghai seeing reduced declines. This improvement may reflect seasonal patterns, as January–February price drops historically narrow by an average of 0.09 percentage points, with January 2026’s 0.12-point narrowing slightly exceeding seasonality. Additionally,挂牌量 (listings volume) has declined seasonally: 256 million units in 58 Anjuke’s national data and 293 million in 26 cities via the Bingshan Index, both down from December 2025. For new homes, sales remain under pressure: after lunar adjustment, 67 cities saw a -44.7% year-on-year decline in sales area, worsening from December’s -27.9%. Top 100 developers’ sales dropped 27.3% year-on-year. However, new home prices rose slightly, averaging 17,000 RMB/m² in January 2026, up 0.18% month-on-month, driven by high-end improvement projects in cities like Chengdu, Shanghai, and Hangzhou. Despite a slight decline in total inventory—from 53 billion m² to 51 billion m²—sales contraction has lengthened the overall absorption cycle from 78 to 84 months, indicating persistent market pressure. The data suggests temporary improvements in second-hand homes are likely due to seasonal and base effects, while new home markets continue to face significant challenges.
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 10, 2026 03:13 AM
Source:[中华网科技公司](https://news.china.com/socialgd/10000169/20260210/49240536.html)

**U.S. January CPI May Surpass Expectations Amid Tariff and Seasonal Pressures**
The U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics is set to release January 2026 Consumer Price Index (CPI) data on February 13, with growing concerns that it may exceed expectations. Inflation has not shown signs of easing, which could delay further interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve (Fed). Economists forecast a 0.3% month-over-month and 2.5% year-over-year increase, but a sharper-than-expected rise is possible. Past trends show January CPI has consistently exceeded forecasts in 2023 and 2024. Two key factors could drive this: first, tariffs imposed under the Trump administration, which are largely absorbed by U.S. importers who pass costs on through price hikes; inventory buffers built before tariffs took effect have now depleted, leading to visible price increases in high-import items like electronics and computers, as shown by Adobe’s e-commerce data. Second, 'residual seasonality'—a persistent upward bias in January CPI due to seasonal price adjustments that do not fully eliminate annual January increases in gym memberships, streaming subscriptions, and medical costs. According to the Boston Fed, January CPI readings remain about 0.03 percentage points higher than other months. If January CPI comes in above expectations, it could derail market expectations of a rate cut starting in June. However, some analysts argue inflation remains manageable, citing price reductions by major U.S. food companies like PepsiCo and General Mills, driven by consumer demand for lower-cost private-label products amid ongoing cost-of-living pressures. This suggests companies are now less able to raise prices freely compared to past periods.
Original language: ko
Publish date: February 09, 2026 08:49 PM
Source:[First-Class 경제신문 파이낸셜뉴스](https://www.fnnews.com/news/202602100428386945)

**US stocks open in the red: Dow down over 100 points, Nasdaq slips 0.4%**
US stocks opened lower on Monday, February 9, 2026, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 128 points (0.2%), the S&P 500 declining 0.2%, and the Nasdaq Composite slipping 0.4%, reflecting renewed pressure on technology and growth-oriented stocks. This followed a volatile week, including a historic rally on Friday, February 6, 2026, when the Dow closed above 50,000 for the first time—rising 1,200 points (2.5%)—after a sharp sell-off driven by weakness in software and tech stocks. The Nasdaq Composite gained over 2% on Friday, while Bitcoin rebounded from below $61,000 to above $70,000. Investors remained cautious ahead of key economic data, including the delayed January nonfarm payrolls report, scheduled for release on Wednesday, February 11, 2026, which economists forecast will show a gain of about 55,000 jobs, with an expected downward revision to prior payroll figures due to the annual benchmark update. The January consumer price index (CPI), also delayed by the government shutdown, is due Friday and is expected to show a 2.5% annual inflation rate. Additionally, Federal Reserve officials, including Governors Christopher Waller and Stephen Miran, are set to speak, offering insight into monetary policy outlooks. On the corporate front, Coca-Cola and Ford Motor are scheduled to report earnings on Tuesday, potentially influencing sector rotation away from high-growth tech stocks. According to Invezz, the market’s cautious tone reflects concerns over inflation, labor market strength, and shifting investment flows.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 09, 2026 03:05 PM
Source:[Invezz](https://invezz.com/news/2026/02/09/us-stocks-open-in-the-red-dow-down-over-100-points-nasdaq-slips-0-4/)

**Goldman traders warn stock selling to continue in choppy US markets**
Goldman Sachs' trading desk warns that US stock selling will continue in a choppy market environment, driven by trend-following algorithmic funds known as Commodity Trading Advisers (CTAs). The S&P 500 has already breached its short-term trigger for CTA selling, with Goldman projecting these systematic strategies to remain net sellers regardless of market direction. A renewed decline could trigger up to $33 billion in selling this week, and if the index falls below 6,707, an additional $80 billion in systematic selling could be unlocked over the next month. Even in a flat market, CTAs are expected to sell $15.4 billion of US equities this week, and if stocks rise, they would still unload about $8.7 billion. Investor stress remains high, with Goldman's Panic Index at 9.22—indicating markets are near 'max fear' levels. S&P 500 top-of-book liquidity has deteriorated sharply to $4.1 million from a year-to-date average of $13.7 million, increasing intraday volatility and delaying price stabilization. Option dealer positioning has shifted from long gamma to flat to short gamma, amplifying moves in low-liquidity conditions. Other systematic strategies, such as risk-parity and volatility-control funds, are also in high-de-risking positions (81st and 71st percentiles, respectively), suggesting their impact could grow if volatility remains elevated. Seasonality adds pressure, as February historically brings choppiness after January's supportive flows fade. Retail investors are showing signs of fatigue, with $690 million in net selling over two days, signaling reduced appetite for 'buying all dips'—particularly in crypto and crypto-linked equities. The S&P 500 had surged 2% on Friday, its biggest gain since May, following a sharp early-week drop triggered by the launch of Anthropic PBC's new AI automation tool, which caused billions in losses across software, financial services, and asset management stocks. Futures on the S&P 500 were up 0.2% at 8:27 p.m. in New York.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 09, 2026 03:15 AM
Source:[Business Standard](https://www.business-standard.com/markets/news/goldman-traders-warn-stock-selling-to-continue-in-choppy-us-markets-126020900085_1.html)

**Goldman Sachs traders warn stock selling isn't over in choppy market - CNBC TV18**
Goldman Sachs' trading desk warns that stock selling in the US market is not over, citing continued pressure from Commodity Trading Advisers (CTAs) and low liquidity. The S&P 500 has already triggered its short-term sell signal for CTAs, systematic strategies that follow market trends rather than fundamentals. Goldman expects CTAs to remain net sellers regardless of market direction, with up to $33 billion in selling possible this week. If the S&P 500 falls below 6,707, an additional $80 billion in systematic selling could be unlocked over the next month. Even in a flat market, CTAs are projected to sell $15.4 billion, and if stocks rise, they may still shed $8.7 billion. Investor stress is high, with Goldman's Panic Index at 9.22—near 'max fear' levels. The S&P 500 surged 2% on Friday, its biggest gain since May, following a sharp mid-week drop triggered by the launch of Anthropic PBC's new AI automation tool, which caused billions in losses across software, financial services, and asset management stocks. S&P 500 top-of-book liquidity has collapsed to $4.1 million, down from a year-to-date average of $13.7 million, increasing intraday volatility. Option dealer positioning has shifted from long gamma to flat to short gamma, amplifying market swings during low-liquidity periods. Risk-parity and volatility-control strategies remain elevated, with risk-parity in the 81st percentile and volatility-control in the 71st percentile over the past year, suggesting further de-risking if volatility persists. Seasonally, February is historically weak and choppy as January's supportive flows fade. Retail investors are showing fatigue, with $690 million in net selling in the last two days, signaling reduced appetite for 'buying all dips.' Crypto-linked equities have been hit hard, raising the risk of a broader rotation out of US stocks.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 09, 2026 01:34 AM
Source:[cnbctv18.com](https://www.cnbctv18.com/market/us-market-snp-500-goldman-sachs-traders-warn-stock-selling-isnt-over-in-choppy-market-ws-l-19845132.htm)

**Stock Index Futures Rise, Gold Reclaims $5,000, Silver Surges Nearly 3% Amid Volatility and Bullish Long-Term Outlook**
On February 9, 2026, U.S. stock index futures rose further in the early Asian session, with the S&P 500 futures up 0.30%, Nasdaq futures up 0.41%, and Dow futures up 0.26% as of 7:52 a.m. Gold prices surged, with spot gold rising over 1% to reach $5,017 per ounce, reclaiming the $5,000 level. Spot silver jumped nearly 3% to $79.86 per ounce. The Guotou Silver LOF announced it would suspend trading from the opening of February 9, 2026, until 10:30 a.m., with potential further measures if premium levels remain elevated; it had already halted subscriptions since January 28, 2026. Silver’s higher volatility compared to gold is attributed to its smaller market size and lower liquidity. Major banks and asset managers reaffirmed their long-term bullish outlook on gold, with Fidelity International’s fund manager indicating readiness to re-enter and PIMCO’s commodities team confirming the uptrend remains intact. JPMorgan’s Jason Hunter described the recent gold price movement as a typical short-term consolidation after rapid gains, not a reversal of the long-term bull trend. Technical analysis shows signs of weakening momentum after a parabolic rise, with Hunter predicting a broad consolidation phase (‘holding pattern’) over the coming weeks or months, where the $5,000 level and the $5,100–$5,150 range will act as strong resistance. Despite near-term technical corrections, the core bullish thesis—‘currency debasement’—remains valid. Hunter emphasized that the U.S. Dollar Index (DXY) has remained below 100, signaling long-term dollar weakness, which could reignite the bearish trend in dollar-denominated assets. Galaxy Securities expects metals to remain in a consolidation phase, urging attention to the U.S. January CPI data to assess inflation persistence and revise Fed policy expectations. In the medium to long term, the bull case for precious metals has shifted from short-term interest rate speculation to hedging against long-term dollar credit risk and global monetary system restructuring. Silver is cautioned for its susceptibility to manipulation due to low liquidity and leveraged capital risks. Industrial metals are expected to benefit from the global green transition, supporting long-term demand. Zhejiang Securities notes that while short-term risks from liquidity shocks and risk-on/off shifts may affect gold and silver, the long-term outlook favors gold over silver. A key entry signal is the decline of gold’s implied volatility (Gold VIX) to a stable range, indicating reduced liquidity stress and improved risk-return profile, signaling a favorable window for medium-term gold investment.
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 09, 2026 12:26 AM
Source:[星岛环球网](https://www.stnn.cc/c/2026-02-09/4036867.shtml)

**Hong Kong Stock Market Weekly Outlook: CICC and Other Companies to Release Earnings, Key Domestic Macroeconomic Data Released**
This week in Hong Kong, several key financial and economic events are expected. On Tuesday, February 10, the U.S. will release the January New York Fed one-year inflation expectation and December retail sales monthly change, while Federal Reserve Governor Waller speaks on digital assets and Atlanta Fed President Bostic discusses monetary policy and economic outlook. On Wednesday, February 11, the U.S. will release January unemployment rate and nonfarm payrolls data, with speeches from Cleveland Fed President Harker and Dallas Fed President Logan. On Thursday, February 12, the U.S. will release the weekly initial jobless claims. On Friday, February 13, the U.S. will release January CPI data, with Logan delivering a welcome speech and Federal Reserve Governor Millin attending an event. The Munich Security Conference runs from February 13 to 15, and EU defense ministers meet in Brussels. In China, the People's Bank of China (PBOC) will have 4,055 billion yuan in reverse repurchase agreements maturing from Monday to Friday, with 5,000 billion yuan in 182-day buyout reverse repos due on Friday. China will release January social financing, new Renminbi loans, CPI, and PPI data on Wednesday, February 11. On Friday, February 13, the National Bureau of Statistics will release the January housing price index report. On Friday, February 14, it will release data on price changes for key production materials in circulation. On Tuesday, February 10, the International Energy Week takes place in London, with the Oslo Energy Forum running concurrently. On Wednesday, February 11, five duty-free shops open in Haikou, Sanya, and Danzhou in Hainan Province. On Thursday, February 12, the African Mining Investment Conference is held in Cape Town. On Sunday, February 15, the 'longest Chinese New Year film season' begins, with eight films confirmed for the 2026 Spring Festival lineup: 'Fast and Furious 3', 'Silent Thunder', 'The Outlaws: Wind in the Great Desert', 'Boonie Bears: Year of the Bear', 'Dreaming in the Galaxy', 'Panda Project: The Tribal Adventure', 'Return to the Wolves', and 'The Night King'. On Wednesday, February 11, NetEase releases its earnings report; the Ministry of Finance will issue 14 billion yuan in RMB bonds in Hong Kong. New share issuance includes先导智能 (00470.HK). On Thursday, February 12, Lenovo Group and Huahong Semiconductor report earnings. On Friday, February 13, Hang Seng Indexes Company announces the 2025 Q4 Hang Seng Index series review results, and Sands China reports earnings.
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 08, 2026 11:39 PM
Source:[东方财富网](https://finance.eastmoney.com/a/202602093644914817.html)

**Wall Street Week Ahead: Investors eye retail sales, inflation, jobs data, Q4 earnings | Stock Market News**
Wall Street is preparing for a data-heavy week following the Dow Jones Industrial Average surpassing the 50,000 milestone for the first time on Friday, February 7, 2026. Market participants are shifting focus toward more affordable small-cap stocks while assessing risks tied to high-valued AI hyperscalers. Key economic indicators to be released include rescheduled December retail sales, the January Consumer Price Index (CPI), January employment data, housing market figures, the NFIB optimism index for January, the Employment Cost Index for Q4, the Import Price Index for December, and Business Inventories for November. On February 11, the U.S. employment report and unemployment rate for January will be released, along with the monthly federal budget. On February 12, initial jobless claims for the week ending February 7 and existing home sales for January will be published. The CPI for January is scheduled for release on February 13. In earnings, major companies including Coca-Cola, McDonald's, Cisco, Ford, AstraZeneca, and Applied Materials will report Q4 results. Bitcoin surged 13% on Friday, reaching $71,469—the highest in nearly three years—recovering most of the value lost during a 50% drop from its October record high. On Friday, the S&P 500 rose 133.90 points (2%) to 6,932.30, the Dow Jones gained 1,206.95 points (2.5%) to 50,115.67, the Nasdaq composite rose 490.63 points (2.2%) to 23,031.21, and the Russell 2000 advanced 92.69 points (3.6%) to 2,670.34.

**Upcoming Capital Market Events: U.S. Inflation and Non-Farm Data, Chinese Tech Earnings, and AI Model Launches**
Next week features a series of major financial and economic events globally. In China, the People's Bank of China will release January CPI and PPI data on February 11, followed by the National Bureau of Statistics releasing the January housing price index on February 13 and the price changes of key production materials on February 14. Additional financial data, including January social financing and new RMB loans, will also be published. Internationally, the U.S. will release January retail sales, unemployment rate, non-farm employment, and CPI data on February 10–13, while the UK and Eurozone will release Q4 GDP data on February 12 and 13. The People's Bank of China will see 4,055 billion yuan in reverse repurchase agreements mature from February 10–14, with an additional 5,000 billion yuan in 182-day buyout reverse repos maturing on Friday. On the geopolitical front, U.S. President Trump announced on February 6 that the U.S. will resume talks with Iran, reiterating that Iran must not acquire nuclear weapons. In the tech sector, DeepSeek is reportedly planning to launch its V4 model around mid-February, with ByteDance and Alibaba expected to unveil Douyin Bot 2.0 and Tongyi Qianwen 3.5 respectively during the Spring Festival period. The Hang Seng Index Company will announce the results of its Q4 2025 index review on February 13. Tesla CEO Elon Musk announced that starting February 14, the FSD (Full Self-Driving) one-time purchase option will be discontinued globally, with the feature now available only via monthly subscription. The 'longest Chinese New Year movie season' (February 15–23) will officially begin next week, with eight films confirmed for the 2026 Spring Festival lineup: 'Fast & Furious 3', 'Silent in the Storm', 'The Outlaws: The Wind of the Great Desert', 'Boonie Bears: Year of the Bear', 'Dreaming in the Star River', 'Panda Project: The Tribe Adventure', 'Return to the Wolves', and 'The Night King'. The Ministry of Finance will issue the first RMB government bond of 2026 in Hong Kong on February 11, with a scale of 14 billion yuan. Meanwhile, Hainan will open five duty-free stores in Haikou, Sanya, and Danzhou on February 11, coinciding with the Southern Winter Solstice Festival.

**S&P Cotality Case-Shiller Index: Home Prices Increase For Fourth Straight Month**
Home prices in the United States rose for the fourth consecutive month in November 2025, according to the S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller Index. The seasonally adjusted 10-city national home price index increased by 0.4% month-over-month and 2.0% year-over-year. However, year-over-year home price growth of 1.4% lagged behind 2.7% inflation, resulting in a 1.3 percentage point real decline in home values. Chicago (+5.7%), New York (+5.0%), and Cleveland (+3.4%) led in annual gains, while Tampa (-3.9%), Phoenix (-1.4%), and Dallas (-1.4%) recorded annual declines. Thirty-year mortgage rates in the mid-6% range are constraining affordability and limiting price growth, keeping real home values flat despite nominal increases. The data was originally published on January 27, 2026, by Jennifer Nash, and republished on January 29, 2026, by Seeking Alpha.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 29, 2026 04:50 AM
Source:[Seeking Alpha](https://seekingalpha.com/article/4863664-s-p-cotality-case-shiller-index-home-prices-increase-for-fourth-straight-month)

**S&P Cotality Case-Shiller Index Reports Annual Gain In November 2025 - S&P Global (NYSE:SPGI)**
The S&P Cotality Case-Shiller U.S. National Home Price NSA Index recorded a 1.4% annual gain in November 2025, matching October’s rate and remaining near the weakest level since mid-2023. Despite this nominal increase, real home values declined as consumer inflation (2.7%) outpaced price growth by 1.3 percentage points. Regional disparities persisted: Chicago led with a 5.7% year-over-year gain, followed by New York (5.0%) and Cleveland (3.4%), while Sun Belt markets declined—Tampa (-3.9%), Phoenix (-1.4%), Dallas (-1.4%), and Miami (-1.0%). On a month-over-month basis, the National Index dropped 0.1% non-seasonally adjusted but rose 0.4% after seasonal adjustment. The 10-City Composite rose 2.0% annually (up from 1.9%), and the 20-City Composite increased 1.4% (up from 1.3%). High mortgage rates—hovering in the mid-6% range—continued to constrain affordability and limit price growth. Detroit’s index was not updated for November 2025 due to transaction delays in Wayne County, though October 2025 data was released. Nicholas Godec, Head of Fixed Income Tradables & Commodities at S&P DJI, stated that 'the housing market has entered a period of tepid growth' and that 'home values have effectively edged down over the past year' in real terms. The indices are published monthly and are based on matched price pairs from arm’s-length home sales across the U.S. Census divisions.

**Newsletter: Case-Shiller: National House Price Index Up 1.4% year-over-year in October**
The S&P/Case-Shiller National Home Price Index rose 1.4% year-over-year in October, according to data released on December 30, 2025, by Calculated Risk. The October figure is based on a three-month average of closing prices from August, September, and October, introducing a significant lag—August prices include contracts signed in June. The seasonally adjusted National Index increased 0.37% month-over-month (MoM), marking the third consecutive month of MoM growth following five consecutive months of MoM declines. This shift suggests a potential stabilization in the national housing market, though the data remains subject to timing lags due to the reporting methodology.

**S&P COTALITY CASE-SHILLER INDEX REPORTS ANNUAL GAIN IN SEPTEMBER 2025**
The S&P Cotality Case-Shiller Indices reported a 1.3% annual gain in the U.S. National Home Price Index for September 2025, the weakest performance since mid-2023, down from 1.4% in August. All 20 metropolitan areas recorded month-over-month declines before seasonal adjustment, with Tampa posting the sharpest annual drop at -4.1%, marking its 11th consecutive month of negative returns. Chicago led with a 5.5% annual gain, followed by New York (5.2%) and Boston (4.1%), while Phoenix (-2.0%), Dallas (-1.3%), and Miami (-1.3%) remained in negative territory. The national index posted a -0.3% month-over-month decline before seasonal adjustment, with only a 0.2% gain after adjustment. Regional divergence was evident: Sun Belt markets, which surged during the pandemic, are now experiencing price declines, while Northeastern and Midwestern metros continue to show resilience. Nicholas Godec, Head of Fixed Income Tradables & Commodities at S&P DJI, attributed the slowdown to elevated mortgage rates near 6.3% and affordability pressures, noting that home prices are now trailing inflation by 1.7 percentage points—the widest gap since June 2024. Over the past six months, national home prices rose just 0.4% in nominal terms and declined in real terms, with only seven of 20 metros posting positive growth. The report emphasized a shift from pandemic-driven migration trends to fundamentals like job markets. Wayne County, MI, data was delayed, preventing a valid Detroit index update for September 2025. The indices are published monthly and are based on matched price pairs from arm’s-length home sales across U.S. census divisions.
Original language: en
Publish date: November 25, 2025 04:12 PM
Source:[PR Newswire](https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/sp-cotality-case-shiller-index-reports-annual-gain-in-september-2025-302625851.html)

**S&P COTALITY CASE-SHILLER INDEX REPORTS ANNUAL GAIN IN SEPTEMBER 2025 - S&P Global (NYSE:SPGI)**
The S&P Cotality Case-Shiller U.S. National Home Price NSA Index recorded a 1.3% annual gain in September 2025, down from 1.4% in August, marking the weakest annual performance since mid-2023. Inflation outpaced home prices for the fourth consecutive month, with September's CPI rising 1.7 percentage points above housing appreciation—the widest gap since the measures diverged in June. All 20 tracked metropolitan areas reported month-over-month declines before seasonal adjustment, indicating broad-based weakening due to elevated mortgage rates (near 6.3% in late September) undermining affordability and demand. Regional performance showed stark contrasts: Chicago led with a 5.5% annual gain, followed by New York (5.2%) and Boston (4.1%), while Tampa recorded the sharpest decline at -4.1%, its 11th consecutive month of negative annual returns. Phoenix (-2.0%), Dallas (-1.3%), and Miami (-1.3%) also remained in negative territory, highlighting ongoing weakness in Sun Belt markets that saw the largest pandemic-era surges. After seasonal adjustment, the National Index rose 0.2%, and the 10-City and 20-City Composites increased 0.2% and 0.1%, respectively. Over the past six months, national home prices rose only 0.4% nominally—negative in real, inflation-adjusted terms—with only seven of the 20 metros showing positive appreciation. Nicholas Godec, Head of Fixed Income Tradables & Commodities at S&P DJI, stated that the market appears to be settling into a new equilibrium of minimal growth or decline, with persistent headwinds from high mortgage rates and historically low affordability. Wayne County, MI, data delays prevented the Detroit index update for September 2025, and missing values will be calculated when data resumes.

**Case-Shiller: National House Price Index Up 1.5% year-over-year in August**
The S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller U.S. National Home Price Index reported a 1.5% year-over-year increase in August 2025, down from 1.6% in July, marking the weakest annual gain in over two years. The 10-City Composite rose 2.1% annually, down from 2.3%, and the 20-City Composite increased 1.6%, down from 1.8%. All three indices posted negative month-over-month changes in their pre-seasonally adjusted forms: -0.3% for the National Index, -0.6% for both the 10-City and 20-City Composites. After seasonal adjustment, all indices rose 0.2% month-over-month. Nineteen of 20 metropolitan areas declined month-to-month, with only Chicago posting a gain, indicating broad weakness beyond typical seasonal trends. Housing wealth continued to erode in real terms for the fourth consecutive month, as the 1.5% nominal national gain fell well short of the 3% inflation rate. New York recorded the highest annual gain at 6.1%, followed by Chicago (5.9%) and Cleveland (4.7%), while Tampa posted the lowest return at -3.3%. Nicholas Godec, Head of Fixed Income Tradables & Commodities at S&P Dow Jones Indices, stated, 'This marks the weakest annual gain in over two years and falls well below the 3% inflation rate. For the fourth straight month, home values have lost ground to inflation, meaning homeowners are seeing their real wealth decline even as nominal prices inch higher.'
Original language: en
Publish date: October 28, 2025 01:45 PM
Source:[CalculatedRisk](http://www.calculatedriskblog.com/2025/10/case-shiller-national-house-price-index.html)
